articles.title: CCMF - Quantitative Methods 2021
articles.contents:
Welcome to Quantitative Methods.
In this course we give you an introduction into common concepts and
tools for data analysis in economics and business. Emphasis will be on
practical data skills as well as the ability to formulate a question
appropriately, provide data analysis relevant to the question and
interpret the results correctly. As part of the course you will be asked
to provide a small piece of data analysis.
Class participation...
To get your participation mark please participate in the Datathon
Forum with either questions or answers or by sharing relevant stuff
(e.g. an interesting dataset or article). You find the forum here.
You should already be enrolled to participate. But if not let me know.
Please only participate with your official Imperial Email address.
Topic 1 - Introduction


More...

Learning Objectives
Understanding what causal relationships are
Become aware of factors that lead to biased estimates of causal
relationships
Understand upward and downward bias
Understand the concept of endogenous and exogenous variation.
Discuss causal identification and biases in the context of a
univariate linear model
Slides

IntroductionESB.pdf
IntroductionESB.pptx

Exercises
Exercises
1
Further reading
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapters 1-3
Causal
Data Science in Large U.S. Firms

Topic 2- Rrrr


More...

We take a first look at the R software package and programming
language, which we will be using throughout this module. For those who
have not yet been programming this will be a steep learning curve.
However, it should be worth it.
You will not be able to analyse data effectively without being
familiar with basic programming concepts. What’s more, to grasp many
aspects of today’s world an understanding of programming is key. Even if
you don’t envisage a career as master coder or data analyst, trying
these things for yourself will be useful as you will very likely have to
manage coders and analysts or rely on their work at some point in your
career.
Learning Objectives
Install R and RStudio on your computer.
Use R as a glorified pocket calculator
Load a dataset and provide simple analysis of it.
Have an understanding of programming concepts such as loops
Be able to merge or join different data sources using code.
Learn how to create data yourself using random number
generators.
Slides

Topic2_Rrrrr.pdf
Topic2_Rrrrr.pptx

Additional Material

FarageGarage.html
FarageGarage.Rmd
Topic2_mostofR4u.docx
Topic2_mostofR4u.html
Topic2_mostofR4u.Rmd
covidNvax_simple.html
covidNvax_simple.nb.html
covidNvax_simple.Rmd

Video Guide: R scripts


Video Guide: Installing R Packages




Video Guide: Functions in R




Exercises
Exercises
2
Further Reading
R
for Data Science
The definite
guide to R Markdown

Topic 3 - Visions


More...

Some of the best ways to understand data are graphs and
visualisations. R has powerful tools for that purpose.
We will be deepening our ability to understand the R programming
language by looking at some of its graphics commands. We will also
discuss some of the pitfalls as well as deliberate manipulations that
people engage in when producing data visualisations.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic3_Visions.pdf
Topic3_Visions.pptx

Additional Material

Topic3_Visions.html
Topic3_Visions.Rmd

The R Graph
Gallery
Exercises
Exercises
3
Further Reading
An
Economist's Guide to Visualizing Data

Topic 4 - Testing Times


More...

We have discussed how to estimate the parameters of a simple
regression model. In this topic we will discuss how work out the
reliability of such estimates. We will examine what determines the
distribution of the estimates and how we can use hypothesis testing to
explore the data and estimates.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic4_TestingTimes.pdf
Topic4_TestingTimes.pptx

Additional Material

Topic4_TestingTimes.html
Topic4_TestingTimes.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
4
Further reading
A
Refresher on Statistical Significance
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 4.5 (Siumlation Study 2)
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 5

Topic 5 - Multivariate
Regressions


More...

we look at multivariate regressions; i.e. regressions where the
dependent variable depends on several – not just one – explanatory
variables.
Learning Objectives
Estimate regression models that depend on multiple explanatory
variables
Be able to interpret output from multivariate regressions
correctly
Understand which variables to include and which ones not to include
to improve causal identification.
Slides

Topic5_TakingBackControl.pdf
Topic5_TakingBackControl.pptx

Additional Material

Topic5_TakingBackControl.html
Topic5_TakingBackControl.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
5
Further Reading
Introduction to
Econometrics with R, Chapter 6
Causal
Inference Mixtape, Pages 65-80

Topic 6 - Econometrics for
Dummies


More...

This might be a course about quantitative analysis, but that doesn’t
mean we can’t handle qualitative issues as well. To capture qualitative
aspects – e.g. an individual in our dataset having a job, the gender of
a person, the location of the headquarters of a company, etc. - we can
use so called dummy or binary variables; i.e. we simply set variable
equal to 1 if the qualitative aspect is true and to 0 if not. We will be
discussing what this means for regression analysis. Moreover, we will be
looking at some nonlinear regression models.
Learning Objectives
Conduct regression analysis with dummy variables
Interpret regression results correctly.
Slides

Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.pdf
Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.pptx

Additional Material

Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.html
Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.Rmd
Tutorial3_2021.html
Tutorial3_2021.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
6
Further Reading
Using R
for Introductory Econometrics Chapter 7
Introduction
to Econometrics Chapters 5.3 and 6.9

Topic 7 - Instrumental
Variables


More...

Suppose you want to know the causal effect of a variable X on a
variable Y but there are concerns that X might be endogenous because of
omitted variable bias for instance. Instrumental variables are variables
that your are not necessarily interested in for their own sake, but that
can help you identify the causal effect that you are interested in
despite the endogeneity.
Learning Objectives
Identify the requirements and conditions that make the Instrumental
Variables approach feasible
Implement Instrumental Variables regressions.
Slides

Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.pdf
Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.pptx

Additional Material

Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.html
Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
7
Further Reading
Introduction to
Econometrics with R, Chapter 12
Introduction
to Econometrics Chapter 12

Topic 8 - Learning like a
machine


More...

You might think studying for this course is so hard that it could
only be done by a machine. After this topic, you'll hopefully think
again.
You will get a brief introduction into Machine Learning. Compared to
the rest of the course, Machine Learning is essentially econometrics
where we are more concerned about prediction rather than the
identification of causal relationships.
Learning Objectives
Explain the basic principles of machine learning
Implement simple machine learning applications.
Slides

Topic8_MachineLearning_Part1.pdf
Topic8_MachineLearning_Part2.pdf

Additional Material
Machine Learning
Competition

Topic8_LearningLikeaMachine.html
Topic8_LearningLikeaMachine.Rmd



Topic 9 - Time for Series


More...

To do any data analysis we need different datapoints. Most data we
looked at so far was cross sectional data; i.e. datapoints derived from
several data units (e.g. individuals, countries, cities, firms).
Alternatively, we might have data for just one data unit but over many
different periods of time (e.g. years, quarters, days or even sometimes
seconds). This creates some specific issues, which we will discuss.
Given that time itself causes a form of confounding and correlation from
one datapoint to the next, we might get some very biased estimates if we
are not careful.
Learning Objectives
Identify the problems related to time series data
Correctly implement causal analysis in a time series context.
Slides

Topic9_TimeSeries.pdf
Topic9_TimeSeries.pptx

Additional Material

Topic9_TimeSeries.html
Topic9_TimeSeries.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
9
Further Reading
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 14 &15

Course Summary Slides
Here
Alternative download location

summary2021.pptx

Group Coursework
As part of this course you are asked to hand in a piece of group
coursework. For this you are asked to provide some simple a short report
on anything you like as long as it involves a discussion of a dataset
and some of the methods we discussed in this class. I.e. think of a good
question, some data and a strategy to say something towards the answer
of the question using data.
You find a template with further instructions here
(RMarkdown
Version).
Past Exam Papers


More...

Past
Exam 1
Past
Exam 2
Past
Exam 3
Past
Exam 4
To prepare also look at Exercises
10

Datasets for past papers (and
more)


More...


- [ back2country_set.dta ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/back2country_set.dta ) 
- [ driving.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/driving.csv ) 
- [ ets_thres_final.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/ets_thres_final.csv ) 
- [ foreigners.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/foreigners.csv ) 
- [ guns.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/guns.csv ) 
- [ hals1prep.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/hals1prep.csv ) 
- [ house.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/house.csv ) 
- [ lfsclean.dta ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/lfsclean.dta ) 
- [ maketable1.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/maketable1.csv ) 
- [ maketable2.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/maketable2.csv ) 
- [ maketable4.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/maketable4.csv ) 
- [ migrants.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/migrants.csv ) 
- [ NH.Ts+dSST.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/NH.Ts+dSST.csv ) 
- [ oj.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/oj.csv ) 
- [ populationclean.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/populationclean.csv ) 
- [ populationdata.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/populationdata.csv ) 
- [ prod.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/prod.csv ) 
- [ prod_balanced.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/prod_balanced.csv ) 
- [ proddata_clean.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/proddata_clean.csv ) 
- [ production2.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/production2.csv ) 
- [ statistic_id183497_population-in-the-states-of-the-us-2019.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/statistic_id183497_population-in-the-states-of-the-us-2019.csv ) 
- [ statistic_id183497_population-in-the-states-of-the-us-2019.xlsx ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/statistic_id183497_population-in-the-states-of-the-us-2019.xlsx ) 
- [ TableWages.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/TableWages.csv ) 
- [ TeachingRatings.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/TeachingRatings.csv ) 
- [ UK Gender Pay Gap Data - 2017 to 2018.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/UK Gender Pay Gap Data - 2017 to 2018.csv ) 
- [ unempprep.csv ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/unempprep.csv ) 
- [ unempprep.dta ]( https://mondpanther.github.io/datastorieshub/data/unempprep.dta )

articles.title: CCMF - Quantitative Methods 2021
articles.contents:
Welcome to Quantitative Methods.
In this course we give you an introduction into common concepts and
tools for data analysis in economics and business. Emphasis will be on
practical data skills as well as the ability to formulate a question
appropriately, provide data analysis relevant to the question and
interpret the results correctly. As part of the course you will be asked
to provide a small piece of data analysis.
Topic 1 - Introduction
Learning Objectives
Understanding what causal relationships are
Become aware of factors that lead to biased estimates of causal
relationships
Understand upward and downward bias
Understand the concept of endogenous and exogenous variation.
Discuss causal identification and biases in the context of a
univariate linear model
Slides

_IntroductionCCMF_old.pptx
IntroductionCCMF.pdf
IntroductionCCMF.pptx

Exercises
Exercises
1
Topic 2- Rrrr
We take a first look at the R software package and programming
language, which we will be using throughout this module. For those who
have not yet been programming this will be a steep learning curve.
However, it should be worth it.
You will not be able to analyse data effectively without being
familiar with basic programming concepts. What’s more, to grasp many
aspects of today’s world an understanding of programming is key. Even if
you don’t envisage a career as master coder or data analyst, trying
these things for yourself will be useful as you will very likely have to
manage coders and analysts or rely on their work at some point in your
career.
Learning Objectives
Install R and RStudio on your computer.
Use R as a glorified pocket calculator
Load a dataset and provide simple analysis of it.
Have an understanding of programming concepts such as loops
Be able to merge or join different data sources using code.
Learn how to create data yourself using random number
generators.
Slides

Topic2_Rrrrr.pptx

Additional Material

FarageGarage.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
2
Topic 3 - Visions
Some of the best ways to understand data are graphs and
visualisations. R has powerful tools for that purpose.
We will be deepening our ability to understand the R programming
language by looking at some of its graphics commands. We will also
discuss some of the pitfalls as well as deliberate manipulations that
people engage in when producing data visualisations.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic3_Visions.pdf
Topic3_Visions.pptx

Additional Material

Topic3_Visions.html
Topic3_Visions.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
3
Topic 4 - Testing Times
We have discussed how to estimate the parameters of a simple
regression model. In this topic we will discuss how work out the
reliability of such estimates. We will examine what determines the
distribution of the estimates and how we can use hypothesis testing to
explore the data and estimates.
## Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.

Topic 5 - Multivariate

we look at multivariate regressions; i.e. regressions where the

Topic 6 - Econometrics for
Dummies
This might be a course about quantitative analysis, but that doesn’t
mean we can’t handle qualitative issues as well. To capture qualitative
aspects – e.g. an individual in our dataset having a job, the gender of

articles.title: ESB - Analytics for Applied Economics and Business
articles.contents:
Welcome to Analytics!
In this course we give you an introduction into common concepts and
tools for data analysis in economics and business. Emphasis will be on
practical data skills as well as the ability to formulate a question
appropriately, provide data analysis relevant to the question and
interpret the results correctly. As part of the course you will be asked
to provide a small piece of data analysis.
Class participation...
To get your participation mark please participate in the Datathon
Forum with either questions or answers or by sharing relevant stuff
(e.g. an interesting dataset or article). You find the forum here.
You should already be enrolled to participate. But if not let me know.
Please only participate with your official Imperial Email address.
Topic 1 - Introduction


More...

Learning Objectives
Understanding what causal relationships are
Become aware of factors that lead to biased estimates of causal
relationships
Understand upward and downward bias
Understand the concept of endogenous and exogenous variation.
Discuss causal identification and biases in the context of a
univariate linear model
Slides

IntroductionESB.pdf
IntroductionESB.pptx

Exercises
Exercises
1
Further reading
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapters 1-3
Causal
Data Science in Large U.S. Firms

Topic 2- Rrrr


More...

We take a first look at the R software package and programming
language, which we will be using throughout this module. For those who
have not yet been programming this will be a steep learning curve.
However, it should be worth it.
You will not be able to analyse data effectively without being
familiar with basic programming concepts. What’s more, to grasp many
aspects of today’s world an understanding of programming is key. Even if
you don’t envisage a career as master coder or data analyst, trying
these things for yourself will be useful as you will very likely have to
manage coders and analysts or rely on their work at some point in your
career.
Learning Objectives

Use R as a glorified pocket calculator

Have an understanding of programming concepts such as loops
Be able to merge or join different data sources using code.
Learn how to create data yourself using random number
generators.

for Data Science

Topic 3 - Visions


More...

Some of the best ways to understand data are graphs and
visualisations. R has powerful tools for that purpose.
We will be deepening our ability to understand the R programming

Further Reading
An
Economist's Guide to Visualizing Data

Topic 4 - Testing Times


More...

We have discussed how to estimate the parameters of a simple
regression model. In this topic we will discuss how work out the
reliability of such estimates. We will examine what determines the
distribution of the estimates and how we can use hypothesis testing to
explore the data and estimates.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic4_TestingTimes.pdf
Topic4_TestingTimes.pptx

Additional Material

Topic4_TestingTimes.html
Topic4_TestingTimes.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
4
Further reading
A
Refresher on Statistical Significance
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 4.5 (Siumlation Study 2)
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 5

Topic 5 - Multivariate
Regressions


More...

we look at multivariate regressions; i.e. regressions where the
dependent variable depends on several – not just one – explanatory
variables.
Learning Objectives
Estimate regression models that depend on multiple explanatory
variables
Be able to interpret output from multivariate regressions
correctly
Understand which variables to include and which ones not to include
to improve causal identification.
Slides

Topic5_TakingBackControl.pdf
Topic5_TakingBackControl.pptx

Additional Material

Topic5_TakingBackControl.html
Topic5_TakingBackControl.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
5
Further Reading
Introduction to
Econometrics with R, Chapter 6
Causal
Inference Mixtape, Pages 65-80

Topic 6 - Econometrics for
Dummies


More...

This might be a course about quantitative analysis, but that doesn’t
mean we can’t handle qualitative issues as well. To capture qualitative
aspects – e.g. an individual in our dataset having a job, the gender of
a person, the location of the headquarters of a company, etc. - we can
use so called dummy or binary variables; i.e. we simply set variable
equal to 1 if the qualitative aspect is true and to 0 if not. We will be
discussing what this means for regression analysis. Moreover, we will be
looking at some nonlinear regression models.
Learning Objectives
Conduct regression analysis with dummy variables
Interpret regression results correctly.
Slides

Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.pdf
Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.pptx

Additional Material

Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.html
Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.Rmd
Tutorial3_2021.html
Tutorial3_2021.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
6
Further Reading
Using R
for Introductory Econometrics Chapter 7
Introduction
to Econometrics Chapters 5.3 and 6.9

Topic 7 - Instrumental
Variables


More...

Suppose you want to know the causal effect of a variable X on a
variable Y but there are concerns that X might be endogenous because of
omitted variable bias for instance. Instrumental variables are variables
that your are not necessarily interested in for their own sake, but that
can help you identify the causal effect that you are interested in
despite the endogeneity.
Learning Objectives
Identify the requirements and conditions that make the Instrumental
Variables approach feasible
Implement Instrumental Variables regressions.
Slides

Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.pdf
Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.pptx

Additional Material

Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.html
Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
7
Further Reading
Introduction to
Econometrics with R, Chapter 12
Introduction
to Econometrics Chapter 12

Topic 8 - Learning like a
machine


More...

You might think studying for this course is so hard that it could
only be done by a machine. After this topic, you'll hopefully think
again.
You will get a brief introduction into Machine Learning. Compared to
the rest of the course, Machine Learning is essentially econometrics
where we are more concerned about prediction rather than the
identification of causal relationships.
Learning Objectives
Explain the basic principles of machine learning
Implement simple machine learning applications.
Slides

Topic8_MachineLearning_Part1.pdf
Topic8_MachineLearning_Part2.pdf

Additional Material
Machine Learning
Competition

Topic8_LearningLikeaMachine.html
Topic8_LearningLikeaMachine.Rmd



Topic 9 - Time for Series


More...

To do any data analysis we need different datapoints. Most data we
looked at so far was cross sectional data; i.e. datapoints derived from
several data units (e.g. individuals, countries, cities, firms).
Alternatively, we might have data for just one data unit but over many
different periods of time (e.g. years, quarters, days or even sometimes
seconds). This creates some specific issues, which we will discuss.
Given that time itself causes a form of confounding and correlation from
one datapoint to the next, we might get some very biased estimates if we
are not careful.
Learning Objectives
Identify the problems related to time series data
Correctly implement causal analysis in a time series context.
Slides

Topic9_TimeSeries.pdf
Topic9_TimeSeries.pptx

Additional Material

Topic9_TimeSeries.html
Topic9_TimeSeries.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
9
Further Reading
Quick
Guide - Unit Roos
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 14 &15

Course Summary Slides
Here

summary2021.pptx

Group Coursework
As part of this course you are asked to hand in a piece of group
coursework. For this you are asked to provide some simple a short report
on anything you like as long as it involves a discussion of a dataset
and some of the methods we discussed in this class. I.e. think of a good
question, some data and a strategy to say something towards the answer
of the question using data.
You find a template with further instructions here
(RMarkdown
Version).
Past graded exercise papers
Graded
Assignment 2019
Graded
Assignment 2018
To prepare also look at Exercises
10
Datasets for past
graded papers (and more)

driving.csv

articles.title: Assessment for SRM
articles.contents:
Exam
2 Open (Essay style) Answer Questions: select 1 , 20
Marks
32 Multiple Choice Questions: 4 answer options, 2.5 Marks each,
with no deduction for a wrong answer.
Example for open questions
see Question
10.4 Question from Exercise sheet 10
Multiple Choice Question
Examples
(To check your understanding select what you think is the correct
option in the dropdown selection menus. If you are right the menu box
should turn blue)
Question 1
Suppose you have estimated the following regression model on a
representative sample of the UK population \[\log(Weight_i)=\beta_0+\beta_1 Female_i+\beta_2
AGE_i +\beta_3+AGE_i^2+\epsilon_i\]
where Weight_i is weight of a person in 100s of kilograms Suppose you
find that \(\hat\beta_1=-0.10\) Which
of the following is a correct interpretation?
The average weight for women is 10kg
Women – on average - weigh 10 kg less than men
Women – on average – weigh 10% less than men
None of the above.
Correct answer
abcd

Question 2
For the model from Question 1: suppose you find that \(\hat\beta_2=0.01\) and \(\hat\beta_3=-0.0001\) . What does it tell
you about the age at which we expect people to be heaviest?
At 25 years
At 75 years
At 40 years
None of the above
Correct answer
abcd


Hint

Because \(\beta_3\) is negative the
weight-age relationship is hump shaped. We can find the maximum of the
hump by setting the gradient equal to 0 implying
\[0.01-2\times 0.0001\times AGE=0\]
Consequently:
\[AGE=\frac{0.01}{2\times
0.0001}=50\]


Question 3
Using a univariate model you obtain a parameter estimate \(\hat\beta=2.1\) with a standard error of
0.1 obtained using a sample size of 1000 observations. Should you reject
the hypothesis that β=1 at the 5% level?
Yes
No
It depends on the variance of the residuals
It depends on the variance of the explanatory variable
abcd


Hint

The t value becomes $t==$21 , which is larger than 1.96, the 5%
critical threshold with a standard normal distribution. Note that 1000
observations we can ignore that the t-statistic is only approximately
normally distributed.


Question 4
The demand for a new drug is known to be linear and downward sloping;
i.e. a higher price means a lower demand. A researcher provided an
estimate of this demand curve but suspects that a confounding factor led
to a downward bias. This means that the estimated curve is
Flatter than it should be
Steeper than it should be
Upward sloping
None of the above
abcd

Question 5
The probability that a standardised normal variable takes a value of
zero or more is:
Equal to zero.
50%
95% for a significance level of 0.1
I need more information on the variance and probability distribution
to answer this question.
abcd
Question 6
The R output below shows a regression of COVID19 cases per student
among US Universities in Fall 2020. The variable partyrank
ranks Universities according to the quality of the local party scene
(i.e. the uni with the best partyscene has rank 1). What does the
regression suggest abou the relationship between party rank and covid
cases?


#simple regression of case on partyrank
lm(casesOstudent~partyrank,datafinal2) %>% summary()



Call:
lm(formula = casesOstudent ~ partyrank, data = datafinal2)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-0.05011 -0.02694 -0.01124  0.01172  0.20685 

Coefficients:
              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  5.937e-02  4.823e-03  12.310  < 2e-16 ***
partyrank   -5.224e-05  1.205e-05  -4.336 2.08e-05 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.04017 on 260 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.06743,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.06384 
F-statistic:  18.8 on 1 and 260 DF,  p-value: 2.078e-05

Moving to one lower rank (e.g from rank 4 to rank 5) ...
... leads to 5.2 students less being affected by covid
... leads to 5.2% less COVID cases.
... leads to 0.52 less COVID cases in 10,000 students.
... leads to 5.2 less COVID cases in 1000 students.
abcd
..
Question 7
The figure below shows the result of a Monte-Carlo study of a
parameter estimate. It's a density plot of the estimated parameter for a
large number of replications along with the true parameter value
(vertical line)


obs=1000
df=data.frame(mc=rnorm(obs)+1)
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(df,aes(x=mc))+geom_density()+geom_vline(xintercept=2,color="red")+theme_minimal()+xlab("")




The estimate is unbiased.
The estimate is upward biased.
The estimate is downward biased
There is not enough information to tell
abcd
Question 8


library(readxl)
set <- read_excel("datastories/worldoilprice/Dataset.xlsx",  skip = 0) %>% 
       rename(oilprice=`WTIspotprice`)



Consider the R output below where the variable oilprice
is the spot price for oil computed at the monthly level from 2010-19.
Based on what is reported below, which of the following can you
conclude:
The oil price is non-stationary at a 5% significance level but not
at 1%.
The oil price is stationary at all significance levels.
The oil price is stationary only at the 10% significance level.
The oil price non-stationary at all significance levels.
abcd


library(urca)
ur.df(set$oilprice) %>% summary()



############################################### 
# Augmented Dickey-Fuller Test Unit Root Test # 
############################################### 

Test regression none 


Call:
lm(formula = z.diff ~ z.lag.1 - 1 + z.diff.lag)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-13.9677  -3.2336   0.6622   3.3823  14.7928 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   
z.lag.1    -0.004069   0.006139  -0.663   0.5088   
z.diff.lag  0.258295   0.089599   2.883   0.0047 **
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 5.05 on 116 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.07005,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.05402 
F-statistic: 4.369 on 2 and 116 DF,  p-value: 0.01481


Value of test-statistic is: -0.6628 

Critical values for test statistics: 
      1pct  5pct 10pct
tau1 -2.58 -1.95 -1.62

Question 9
Consider the R output below where the variable oilprice
is (as in Question 8) the spot price for oil computed at the monthly
level from 2010-19. Based on what is reported below, which of the
following can you conclude:
Oil prices are growing at a rate of 7% on average.
Oil prices are shrinking at a rate of 3.1% on average.
Oil prices are shrinking at a rate of 0.31% on average.
Oil prices are srhinking at a rate of 0.23% on average.
abcd


lm(formula=diff(log(oilprice))~1,set) %>% summary()



Call:
lm(formula = diff(log(oilprice)) ~ 1, data = set)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-0.24327 -0.04393  0.01249  0.04868  0.21612 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) -0.002257   0.007238  -0.312    0.756

Residual standard error: 0.07896 on 118 degrees of freedom

Question 10
Which notation is correct?
\[y_i=β_1+β_2 x_{2i}\]
\[\hat{y}_i=\hat{β}_1+\hat{β}_2
x_{2i}\]
\[\hat{y}_i=β_1+β_2 x_{2i}\]
\[\hat{y}_i=\hat{β}_1+\hat{β}_2
\hat{x}_{2i}\]
abcd

articles.title: JH-IBSc - Social Research Methods 2021
articles.contents:
Welcome to Social Research Methods.
This module consists of two parts:
Part I - Qualitative Research Methods
In this part you will be introduced to the main differences between
qualitative and quantitative methods, before focusing on key themes for
designing and executing qualitative research. In particular, you will
develop an understanding of how to formulate research purposes and
questions to study healthcare organizations, how to choose the research
setting through purposeful sampling, and how to collect and analyse
interview data. You will also familiarize with some of the most relevant
methodologies (e.g., grounded theory, ethnography, etc.)
Part II - Quantitative methods
In this part we give you an introduction into common concepts and
tools for data analysis in economics and business. Emphasis will be on
practical data skills as well as the ability to formulate a question
appropriately, provide data analysis relevant to the question and
interpret the results correctly. As part of the course you will be asked
to provide a small piece of data analysis.
Class participation...
To get your participation mark please participate in the Datathon
Forum with either questions or answers or by sharing relevant stuff
(e.g. an interesting dataset or article). You find the forum here.
You should already be enrolled to participate. But if not let me know.
Please only participate with your official Imperial Email address.
Part I - Qualitative Methods
Week 1
Qualitative Methods 1
In this session, you will learn the main dimensions along which
qualitative and quantitative research differ, and how each set of
methods enables to investigate different phenomena. You will then
explore examples of relevant research questions in healthcare settings
and try your hand at developing your own. You will learn the criteria
for choosing an ideal research setting.
Qualitative Methods 2
In this session, you will learn how to develop interview protocols
and to identify the main issues in collecting interview data for
inductive research. You will also gain familiarity with the main
technique for analysing textual data and with the validity criteria of
inductive theory. Finally, you will get introduced to the main
methodologies for conducting inductive research.
Part II - Quantitative
Methods
Week 2
Topic 1 - Introduction


More...

Learning Objectives
Understanding what causal relationships are
Become aware of factors that lead to biased estimates of causal
relationships
Understand upward and downward bias
Understand the concept of endogenous and exogenous variation.
Discuss causal identification and biases in the context of a
univariate linear model
Slides

IntroductionSRM.pdf
IntroductionSRM.pptx

Exercises
Exercises
1
Further reading
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapters 1-3
Causal
Data Science in Large U.S. Firms

Topic 2 - Rrrr


More...

We take a first look at the R software package and programming
language, which we will be using throughout this module. For those who
have not yet been programming this will be a steep learning curve.
However, it should be worth it.
You will not be able to analyse data effectively without being
familiar with basic programming concepts. What’s more, to grasp many
aspects of today’s world an understanding of programming is key. Even if
you don’t envisage a career as master coder or data analyst, trying
these things for yourself will be useful as you will very likely have to
manage coders and analysts or rely on their work at some point in your
career.
Learning Objectives
Install R and RStudio on your computer.
Use R as a glorified pocket calculator
Load a dataset and provide simple analysis of it.
Have an understanding of programming concepts such as loops
Be able to merge or join different data sources using code.
Learn how to create data yourself using random number
generators.
Slides

Topic2_Rrrrr.pdf
Topic2_Rrrrr.pptx

Additional Material

FarageGarage.html
FarageGarage.Rmd
Topic2_mostofR4u.docx
Topic2_mostofR4u.html
Topic2_mostofR4u.Rmd
covidNvax_simple.html
covidNvax_simple.nb.html
covidNvax_simple.Rmd

Video Guide: R scripts


Video Guide: Installing R Packages




Video Guide: Functions in R




Exercises
Exercises
2
Further Reading
R
for Data Science
The definite
guide to R Markdown
R
- A good friend with a difficult personality

Week 3
Topic 3 - Visions


More...

Some of the best ways to understand data are graphs and
visualisations. R has powerful tools for that purpose.
We will be deepening our ability to understand the R programming
language by looking at some of its graphics commands. We will also
discuss some of the pitfalls as well as deliberate manipulations that
people engage in when producing data visualisations.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic3_Visions.pdf
Topic3_Visions.pptx

Additional Material

Topic3_Visions.html
Topic3_Visions.Rmd

The R Graph
Gallery
Exercises
Exercises
3
Further Reading
An
Economist's Guide to Visualizing Data

Topic 4 - Testing Times


More...

We have discussed how to estimate the parameters of a simple
regression model. In this topic we will discuss how work out the
reliability of such estimates. We will examine what determines the
distribution of the estimates and how we can use hypothesis testing to
explore the data and estimates.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic4_TestingTimes.pdf
Topic4_TestingTimes.pptx

Topic4_TestingTimes.Rmd

A
Refresher on Statistical Significance

to Econometrics with R, Chapter 4.5 (Siumlation Study 2)
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 5

Week 4
Topic 5 - Taking Back
Control


More...

we look at multivariate regressions; i.e. regressions where the
dependent variable depends on several – not just one – explanatory
variables.
Learning Objectives
Estimate regression models that depend on multiple explanatory
variables
Be able to interpret output from multivariate regressions
correctly

Topic5_TakingBackControl.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises

Further Reading

Econometrics with R, Chapter 6
Causal
Inference Mixtape, Pages 65-80

Topic 6 - Econometrics for
Dummies


More...

This might be a course about quantitative analysis, but that doesn’t

to Econometrics Chapters 5.3 and 6.9

Week 5
Topic 7 - Instrumental
Variables


More...

Suppose you want to know the causal effect of a variable X on a
variable Y but there are concerns that X might be endogenous because of

that your are not necessarily interested in for their own sake, but that

Learning Objectives

Topic 9 - Time for Series


More...

To do any data analysis we need different datapoints. Most data we
looked at so far was cross sectional data; i.e. datapoints derived from
several data units (e.g. individuals, countries, cities, firms).
Alternatively, we might have data for just one data unit but over many
different periods of time (e.g. years, quarters, days or even sometimes
seconds). This creates some specific issues, which we will discuss.
Given that time itself causes a form of confounding and correlation from
one datapoint to the next, we might get some very biased estimates if we
are not careful.
Learning Objectives

Correctly implement causal analysis in a time series context.

articles.title: JH-IBSc - Social Research Methods 2021 - Part II( Quantitative Methods)
articles.contents:
Welcome to Social Research Methods - Part II( Quantitative
Methods).
In this course we give you an introduction into common concepts and
tools for data analysis in economics and business. Emphasis will be on
practical data skills as well as the ability to formulate a question
appropriately, provide data analysis relevant to the question and
interpret the results correctly. As part of the course you will be asked
to provide a small piece of data analysis.
Class participation...
To get your participation mark please participate in the Datathon
Forum with either questions or answers or by sharing relevant stuff
(e.g. an interesting dataset or article). You find the forum here.
You should already be enrolled to participate. But if not let me know.
Please only participate with your official Imperial Email address.
Topic 1 - Introduction


More...

Learning Objectives
Understanding what causal relationships are
Become aware of factors that lead to biased estimates of causal
relationships
Understand upward and downward bias
Understand the concept of endogenous and exogenous variation.
Discuss causal identification and biases in the context of a
univariate linear model
Slides

IntroductionESB.pdf
IntroductionESB.pptx

Exercises
Exercises
1
Further reading
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapters 1-3
Causal
Data Science in Large U.S. Firms

Topic 2- Rrrr


More...

We take a first look at the R software package and programming
language, which we will be using throughout this module. For those who
have not yet been programming this will be a steep learning curve.
However, it should be worth it.
You will not be able to analyse data effectively without being
familiar with basic programming concepts. What’s more, to grasp many
aspects of today’s world an understanding of programming is key. Even if
you don’t envisage a career as master coder or data analyst, trying
these things for yourself will be useful as you will very likely have to
manage coders and analysts or rely on their work at some point in your
career.
Learning Objectives
Install R and RStudio on your computer.
Use R as a glorified pocket calculator
Load a dataset and provide simple analysis of it.
Have an understanding of programming concepts such as loops
Be able to merge or join different data sources using code.
Learn how to create data yourself using random number
generators.
Slides

Topic2_Rrrrr.pdf
Topic2_Rrrrr.pptx

Additional Material

FarageGarage.html
FarageGarage.Rmd
Topic2_mostofR4u.docx
Topic2_mostofR4u.html
Topic2_mostofR4u.Rmd

Video Guide: R scripts


Video Guide: Installing R Packages




Video Guide: Functions in R




Exercises
Exercises
2
Further Reading
R
for Data Science
The definite
guide to R Markdown

Topic 3 - Visions


More...

Some of the best ways to understand data are graphs and
visualisations. R has powerful tools for that purpose.
We will be deepening our ability to understand the R programming
language by looking at some of its graphics commands. We will also
discuss some of the pitfalls as well as deliberate manipulations that
people engage in when producing data visualisations.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic3_Visions.pdf
Topic3_Visions.pptx

Additional Material

Topic3_Visions.html
Topic3_Visions.Rmd

The R Graph
Gallery
Exercises
Exercises
3
Further Reading
An
Economist's Guide to Visualizing Data

Topic 4 - Testing Times


More...

We have discussed how to estimate the parameters of a simple
regression model. In this topic we will discuss how work out the
reliability of such estimates. We will examine what determines the
distribution of the estimates and how we can use hypothesis testing to
explore the data and estimates.
Learning Objectives
Use the R programming language to create basic and some more
advanced graphs and visualisations based on data.
Avoid common pitfals that lead to misleading or un-informative
visualisations.
Slides

Topic4_TestingTimes.pdf
Topic4_TestingTimes.pptx

Additional Material

Topic4_TestingTimes.html
Topic4_TestingTimes.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
4
Further reading
A
Refresher on Statistical Significance
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 4.5 (Siumlation Study 2)
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 5

Topic 5 - Multivariate
Regressions


More...

we look at multivariate regressions; i.e. regressions where the
dependent variable depends on several – not just one – explanatory
variables.
Learning Objectives
Estimate regression models that depend on multiple explanatory
variables
Be able to interpret output from multivariate regressions
correctly
Understand which variables to include and which ones not to include
to improve causal identification.
Slides

Topic5_TakingBackControl.pdf
Topic5_TakingBackControl.pptx

Additional Material

Topic5_TakingBackControl.html
Topic5_TakingBackControl.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
5
Further Reading
Introduction to
Econometrics with R, Chapter 6
Causal
Inference Mixtape, Pages 65-80

Topic 6 - Econometrics for
Dummies


More...

This might be a course about quantitative analysis, but that doesn’t
mean we can’t handle qualitative issues as well. To capture qualitative
aspects – e.g. an individual in our dataset having a job, the gender of
a person, the location of the headquarters of a company, etc. - we can
use so called dummy or binary variables; i.e. we simply set variable
equal to 1 if the qualitative aspect is true and to 0 if not. We will be
discussing what this means for regression analysis. Moreover, we will be
looking at some nonlinear regression models.
Learning Objectives
Conduct regression analysis with dummy variables
Interpret regression results correctly.
Slides

Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.pdf
Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.pptx

Additional Material

Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.html
Topic6_EconometricsforDummies.Rmd
Tutorial3_2021.html
Tutorial3_2021.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
6
Further Reading
Using R
for Introductory Econometrics Chapter 7
Introduction
to Econometrics Chapters 5.3 and 6.9

Topic 7 - Instrumental
Variables


More...

Suppose you want to know the causal effect of a variable X on a
variable Y but there are concerns that X might be endogenous because of
omitted variable bias for instance. Instrumental variables are variables
that your are not necessarily interested in for their own sake, but that
can help you identify the causal effect that you are interested in
despite the endogeneity.
Learning Objectives
Identify the requirements and conditions that make the Instrumental
Variables approach feasible
Implement Instrumental Variables regressions.
Slides

Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.pdf
Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.pptx

Additional Material

Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.html
Topic7_InstrumentalVariables.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
7
Further Reading
Introduction to
Econometrics with R, Chapter 12
Introduction
to Econometrics Chapter 12

Topic 8 - Time for Series


More...

To do any data analysis we need different datapoints. Most data we
looked at so far was cross sectional data; i.e. datapoints derived from
several data units (e.g. individuals, countries, cities, firms).
Alternatively, we might have data for just one data unit but over many
different periods of time (e.g. years, quarters, days or even sometimes
seconds). This creates some specific issues, which we will discuss.
Given that time itself causes a form of confounding and correlation from
one datapoint to the next, we might get some very biased estimates if we
are not careful.
Learning Objectives
Identify the problems related to time series data
Correctly implement causal analysis in a time series context.
Slides

Topic9_TimeSeries.pdf
Topic9_TimeSeries.pptx

Additional Material

Topic9_TimeSeries.html
Topic9_TimeSeries.Rmd

Exercises
Exercises
9
Further Reading
Introduction
to Econometrics with R, Chapter 14 &15

Group Coursework
As part of this course you are asked to hand in a piece of group
coursework. For this you are asked to provide some simple a short report
on anything you like as long as it involves a discussion of a dataset
and some of the methods we discussed in this class. I.e. think of a good
question, some data and a strategy to say something towards the answer
of the question using data.
You find a template with further instructions here
(RMarkdown
Version).
Exam Guidelines


More...
